title: Chromatic Reduction by Edge Removal
content: A graph G can have its chromatic number reduced to ≤ r by removing at most k edges. This captures the idea that G is 'close to being r-colorable' — only k edges prevent an r-coloring.

title: Threshold Function f_r(n)
content: f_r(n) is the maximum k such that the condition 'every subgraph reduces to chromatic number ≤ r after removing ≤ k edges' forces χ(G) ≤ r+1. It measures the gap between local reducibility and global coloring.

title: Question 1: f₂(n) ≫ n?
content: Erdős, Hajnal, and Szemerédi asked whether f₂(n)/n → ∞. Tang noted that Rödl's 1982 construction provides evidence against this, showing f₂(n) = O(n·polylog(n)).

title: Question 2: f_r(n) ≫ rn?
content: The general question: does f_r(n)/(rn) → ∞ for every fixed r ≥ 2? This would mean local chromatic reducibility with a budget proportional to rn always forces global (r+1)-colorability.

title: Rödl's Upper Bound (1982)
content: Rödl constructed graphs showing f₂(n) = O(n·(log n)²). This means f₂(n) grows at most slightly super-linearly, casting serious doubt on whether f₂(n) ≫ n is true.

title: Monotonicity and Problem #744
content: f_r(n) is monotone increasing in r: reducing to chromatic number r+1 is easier than to r. This problem is related to Problem #744, which concerns similar chromatic decomposition thresholds.
